text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column page with a full-width framed miniature occupying the upper half; a single line of text in Gothic textura runs beneath the image; wide blank margins surround the miniature creating visual separation between image and text.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with regular letterforms, consistent spacing, use of standard medieval abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for the halo and decorative highlights; deep blue dominates the sail as a symbol of the divine message; green in the waves underscores the earthly sea; red accents on the sail and garments direct the eye to important figures; layered application with white lead highlights on wave crests and robes; original pigments remain vibrant with minimal oxidation.

features: horizontal emphasis of the boat across center
haloed figure placed slightly right of center as focal point
tree on left margin balancing the composition
undulating waves form a rhythmic base
overlapping figures and ship elements suggest depth

decorative_elements: simple green and blue double-line border framing the scene
patterned sail bearing heraldic shields and red flame motifs
stylized tree with birds at left edge acting as marginal ornament
flag atop mast with red cross emblem

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work in brown iron-gall ink with moderately bold outlines and finer internal details
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal parallel hatching; white lead highlights on waves and folds provide volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of the haloed figure; no true linear perspective; depth indicated by overlapping

sub_themes: angelic or divine inspiration (haloed figure writing Revelation)
content_theme.scene_description: A single, full-width scene depicts St. John the Evangelist seated at the prow of a wooden boat, his nimbused head bent over a writing tablet as he inscribes the text of the Apocalypse. Four oarsmen—two on each side—propel the vessel through stylized green waves rendered with white highlights. Two sailors stand mid-ship adjusting a richly patterned sail emblazoned with shields and red flame motifs, while a small pennon bearing a red cross flies from the masthead. On the left margin a slender tree with dark green foliage supports two perched birds, echoing the motif of divine witnesses. Beneath the waves small fish swim among aquatic plants. The figures wear tunics and hoods in blue, green, and red, with gold accents indicating spiritual significance. The composition centers on St. John’s gold halo and writing gesture, with all other elements arranged to draw the viewer’s eye to his sacred task.

religious: St. John with gold halo, seated writing on a tablet

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, smooth surface preparation visible in uniform paint absorption; folio from a quaternion gathering with ruled baselines faintly visible.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight cockling of parchment at edges; minor flaking of red pigment in sail motifs; gold leaf remains burnished.
notable_physical_characteristics: visible brush strokes in wave rendering
fine plummet ruling lines beneath text and miniature
under-drawing traces detectable under UV light

secondary_functions: display of institutional prestige through rich illumination

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This folio, likely produced in a mid-13th-century Northern French workshop, exemplifies the high craftsmanship of Gospel or Apocalypse manuscripts intended for liturgical use. The vibrant ultramarine, verdigris, and burnished gold point to a well-funded commission, perhaps for a cathedral treasury. The centralized composition focuses on St. John’s act of writing, underscoring the theological importance of the Revelation text. The patterned sail, bearing heraldic shields and flame motifs, reflects contemporary interest in decorative heraldry and may allude to the spiritual ‘arms’ bestowed upon the faithful. The stylized tree and fish motifs in the margins and beneath the waves create a visual frame that unites the terrestrial and celestial realms, a common device in 13th-century iconography. The use of Gothic textura suggests a professional scriptorium associated with a cathedral school, while underdrawing visible under UV hints at a two-stage production process involving both draughtsman and colorist. Iconographically, the scene emphasizes the transmission of divine revelation aboard a ship—a motif resonating with the medieval Church’s self-understanding as the vessel of salvation. Comparisons with the Parisian Apocalypse manuscripts reveal similar compositional schemes, yet this miniature’s execution shows unique flourishes in the wave treatment and tree ornament, suggesting regional artistic dialogues between Paris and the Loire Valley workshops.
